012package org.postgresql.pljava.example.annotation;
013
014import java.sql.ResultSet;
015import java.sql.SQLException;
016
017import org.postgresql.pljava.annotation.SQLAction;
018import org.postgresql.pljava.annotation.Function;
019
020/**
021 * Test that strings containing characters from all Unicode planes
022 * are passed between PG and Java without alteration (issue 21).
023 * <p>
024 * This function takes a string and an array of ints constructed in PG, such
025 * that PG believes the codepoints in the string to correspond exactly with the
026 * ints in the array. The function compares the two, generates a new array from
027 * the codepoints Java sees in the string and a new Java string from the
028 * original array, and returns a tuple (matched, cparray, s) where
029 * {@code matched} indicates whether the original array and string matched
030 * as seen by Java, and {@code cparray} and {@code s} are the new array and
031 * string generated in Java.
032 * <p>
033 * The supplied test query generates all Unicode code points 1k at a time,
034 * calls this function on each (1k array, 1k string) pair, and counts a failure
035 * if {@code matched} is false or the original and returned arrays or strings
036 * do not match as seen in SQL.
037 * <p>
038 * This example relies on {@code implementor} tags reflecting the PostgreSQL
039 * version, set up in the {@link ConditionalDDR} example, and also sets its own.
040 */
041@SQLAction(provides="postgresql_unicodetest",
042    implementor="postgresql_ge_90000", install=
043    "SELECT CASE" +
044    " WHEN 'UTF8' = current_setting('server_encoding')" +
045    " THEN set_config('pljava.implementors', 'postgresql_unicodetest,' ||" +
046    " current_setting('pljava.implementors'), true) " +
047    "END"
048)
049@SQLAction(requires="unicodetest fn",
050implementor="postgresql_unicodetest",
051install=
052"   with " +
053"    usable_codepoints ( cp ) as ( " +
054"     select generate_series(1,x'd7ff'::int) " +
055"     union all " +
056"     select generate_series(x'e000'::int,x'10ffff'::int) " +
057"    ), " +
058"    test_inputs ( groupnum, cparray, s ) as ( " +
059"     select " +
060"       cp / 1024 as groupnum, " +
061"       array_agg(cp order by cp), string_agg(chr(cp), '' order by cp) " +
062"     from usable_codepoints " +
063"     group by groupnum " +
064"    ), " +
065"    test_outputs as ( " +
066"     select groupnum, cparray, s, unicodetest(s, cparray) as roundtrip " +
067"     from test_inputs " +
068"    ), " +
069"    test_failures as ( " +
070"     select * " +
071"     from test_outputs " +
072"     where " +
073"      cparray != (roundtrip).cparray or s != (roundtrip).s " +
074"      or not (roundtrip).matched " +
075"    ), " +
076"    test_summary ( n_failing_groups, first_failing_group ) as ( " +
077"     select count(*), min(groupnum) from test_failures " +
078"    ) " +
079"   select " +
080"    case when n_failing_groups > 0 then " +
081"     javatest.logmessage('WARNING', n_failing_groups || " +
082"      ' 1k codepoint ranges had mismatches, first is block starting 0x' || " +
083"      to_hex(1024 * first_failing_group)) " +
084"    else " +
085"     javatest.logmessage('INFO', " +
086"        'all Unicode codepoint ranges roundtripped successfully.') " +
087"    end " +
088"    from test_summary"
089)
090@SQLAction(
091    install=
092        "CREATE TYPE unicodetestrow AS " +
093        "(matched boolean, cparray integer[], s text)",
094    remove="DROP TYPE unicodetestrow",
095    provides="unicodetestrow type"
096)
097public class UnicodeRoundTripTest {
098    /**
099     * This function takes a string and an array of ints constructed in PG,
100     * such that PG believes the codepoints in the string to correspond exactly
101     * with the ints in the array. The function compares the two, generates a
102     * new array from the codepoints Java sees in the string and a new Java
103     * string from the original array, and returns a tuple (matched, cparray,
104     * s) where {@code matched} indicates whether the original array and string
105     * matched as seen by Java, and {@code cparray} and {@code s} are the new
106     * array and string generated in Java.
107     *
108     * @param s A string, whose codepoints should match the entries of
109     *        {@code ints}
110     * @param ints Array of ints that should match the codepoints in {@code s}
111     * @param rs OUT (matched, cparray, s) as described above
112     * @return true to indicate the OUT tuple is not null
113     */
114    @Function(type="unicodetestrow",
115        requires="unicodetestrow type", provides="unicodetest fn")
116    public static boolean unicodetest(String s, int[] ints, ResultSet rs)
117    throws SQLException {
118        boolean ok = true;
119
120        int cpc = s.codePointCount(0, s.length());
121        Integer[] myInts = new Integer[cpc];
122        int ci = 0;
123        for ( int cpi = 0; cpi < cpc; cpi++ ) {
124            myInts[cpi] = s.codePointAt(ci);
125            ci = s.offsetByCodePoints(ci, 1);
126        }
127
128        String myS = new String(ints, 0, ints.length);
129
130        if ( ints.length != myInts.length )
131            ok = false;
132        else
133            for ( int i = 0; i < ints.length; ++ i )
134    if ( ints[i] != myInts[i] )
135        ok = false;
136
137        rs.updateBoolean("matched", ok);
138        rs.updateObject("cparray", myInts);
139        rs.updateString("s", myS);
140        return true;
141    }
142}
